ThingDef.Name: STAMM_RA
ThingDef.label: Stamm-Saurer M1913
ThingDef.description: From 1908 to 1920, Hans Stamm from St. Gallen constructed various repeating and self-loading rifles for the Adolph Saurer company in Arbon. This example is of his 1913 pattern of self-loading rifle.

ThingDef.Name: FARQUHAR
ThingDef.label: Farquhar-Hill M1918
ThingDef.description: The Farquhar-Hill was tested in May 1908, but was rejected due to it having a number of faults. Despite many improved designs following, the rifle never managed to completely satisfy the Small Arms committee. One example was trialed in the United States late into World War I. The British Army ordered and adopted the rifle in 1918, but all orders were cancelled due to the war ending.

ThingDef.Name: FEG_PT
ThingDef.label: Frommer FÉG Self-Loader
ThingDef.description: The Frommer Self-Loader is a prototype Hungarian Semi-Auto rifle. This is a very rare and certainly unique, early Hungarian prototype semi-automatic rifle patented by Rudolf Frommer and manufactured at the FEG factory in Hungary.

ThingDef.Name: GUN_LUGERRIFLE
ThingDef.label: Luger M1906
ThingDef.description: The Luger M1906 is a scaled-up version of Georgs' Luger pistol design. Chambering 7.92 Mauser, only one example is known to exist in Switzerland.

ThingDef.Name: Meunier
ThingDef.label: Meunier A6
ThingDef.description: The Meunier A6 was a French Semi-Automatic rifle that was chosen to be adopted by the French military post trials. It never saw any substantial service as when war were declared, the project was mostly cancelled. Some 1000 rifles were made in 1917 as a Stop-gap.

ThingDef.Name: GRIFFITHSWOODGATE
ThingDef.label: Griffiths-Woodgate
ThingDef.description: The Griffiths-Woodgate rifle was a British automatic rifle, designed in 1891 by William Griffiths and Herbert Ferdinand Woodgate. It is thought to be the world's first automatic rifle.

ThingDef.Name: MONDRAGON
ThingDef.label: Mondrágon M1917
ThingDef.description: The Mondrágon M1917 is a Swiss modified M1908 Mondrágon rifle in 7.5mm Swiss with an extended 12 round magazine. Only a handful were made for Swiss trials.

ThingDef.Name: SELBSTLADER1916
ThingDef.label: Mauser Selbstlader 1916 Infantry
ThingDef.description: The Selbstlader Infantry was an attempt by Mauser to get a wide spread adoption of a Self loading rifle for the German Imperial Army. Though it's complex design made the gun unusable in trench fighting conditions.

ThingDef.Name: ROSSSEMIAUTORIFLE
ThingDef.label: Ross Semiauto Prototype
ThingDef.description: The “Ross” Semiauto Prototype Rifle is a truly forgotten weapon. Almost nothing is known about this firearm. Except it uses Ross Rifle furniture and a Ross Rifle M1910 magazine.

ThingDef.Name: STENDEBACH
ThingDef.label: Stendebach M1936
ThingDef.description: The Stendebach M1936 was a pre-WW2 design that was captured by the Americans at the end of WW2. Only 2 are known to exist today.

ThingDef.Name: HOLUB
ThingDef.label: Holub Light Rifle
ThingDef.description: The Holub was a full-auto 5 round capacity SLR/LMG hybrid made in the 1920s in Czechoslovakia.

ThingDef.Name: SJOGRENKARABINER
ThingDef.label: Sjögren Karabiner M1909
ThingDef.description: The Sjögren M1909 is a self-loading conversion of a M1893 Swedish Mauser carbine.

ThingDef.Name: BJORGUMSL
ThingDef.label: Bjorgum M/1916
ThingDef.description: The Bjorgum was a Swedish made, Norwegian designed self-loading rifle made for Norwegian trials. It was drafted by a Norwegian painter named Nils Bjorgum, who, after his failed attempt at gun designing, became a famous painter.

ThingDef.Name: MADSEN1896
ThingDef.label: Madsen M1896 Flaadens Rekylgevær
ThingDef.description: The Madsen M1896 was the first Self-loading rifle to be used in any military on the world. The Danish bought 40-50 rifles to be used as coastal defense guns.

ThingDef.Name: BANGM1927
ThingDef.label: Bang M1927
ThingDef.description: Soren Hansen Bang was a Danish gun designer that invented the "Bang" system for self-loading rifles, using the residual gas trapped by a muzzle device to cycle the weapon. This example is one of his later models, tested by the British in 1927.

ThingDef.Name: MANNLICHERM1901/04
ThingDef.label: Mannlicher M1901/04 Carbine
ThingDef.description: The Mannlicher M1901/04 semi-automatic carbine prototype was developed from Mannlicher’s M1896 semi-automatic pistol.

ThingDef.Name: DREYSE32
ThingDef.label: Dreyse M1907 .32 ACP
ThingDef.description: The Dreyse M1907 Carbine was manufactured by Rheinmetall and designed by Louis Stange. It uses the same basic action as the Dreyse Model 1907 pistol.

ThingDef.Name: FRANCOTTE
ThingDef.label: Francotte M1910
ThingDef.description: The Francotte Model 1910 is a Belgian semi-automatic lever action takedown rifle.

ThingDef.Name: PIEPERCARBINE
ThingDef.label: Pieper Model 1893 Revolving Carbine
ThingDef.description: The Pieper Revolving Carbine is a Belgian rifle which utilizes the gas seal system from the Nagant M1895 revolver. It saw use by the Mexican Rurales police force near the end of the 19th century.

ThingDef.Name: ZH29
ThingDef.label: ZH-29
ThingDef.description: The ZH-29 was designed by Emmanuel Holek in the late 1920s. Despite generally receiving positive feedback from the countries in which it was trialed, the ZH-29 received few orders. It saw limited export sales to Abyssinia, China, and Siam. The Chinese fielded it against the Japanese during the Second Sino-Japanese War.

ThingDef.Name: WZ38
ThingDef.label: Kbsp wz.38M
ThingDef.description: The Karabin samopowtarzalny wzór 38M, Kbsp wz.38M for short, was a Polish 7.92 mm semi-automatic rifle. The only documented use of this rifle was by Józef Maroszek himself as he was fleeing the factory that he worked at, shooting at 2 Stukas and allegedly downing one of them.

ThingDef.Name: STEYRM1911
ThingDef.label: Steyr M1911 Self-Loader
ThingDef.description: The Steyr Self-Loader was a prototype Semi-Auto rifle made in Austria-Hungary before WW1. It didn't get adopted because of Austrian worries of the possibility of a new war.

ThingDef.Name: GENERALLIUSEMI
ThingDef.label: General Liu
ThingDef.description: The General Liu was a chinese Semi-auto rifle. Almost adopted and mass produced, sadly it's designer had a stroke before being able to start production. This rifle also featured a selectable fire-mode in which you could switch it into a Straight-pull bolt action.

ThingDef.Name: MAS191821
ThingDef.label: MAS 1918/21
ThingDef.description: The MAS 1918/21 was an attempt by Manufacture d'Armes de Saint-Étienne to make an Semi-automatic rifle for the French army post WW1.

ThingDef.Name: RSC1918
ThingDef.label: RSC Mle 1918
ThingDef.description: The RSC 1918 was the updated Carbine version of the original M1917 rifle.

ThingDef.Name: BERETTAM1918-30
ThingDef.label: Beretta M1918-30
ThingDef.description: Starting in 1930, Beretta re-purposed many surplus M1918s into semi-automatic carbines known as the M1918/30.

ThingDef.Name: BERT31
ThingDef.label: Beretta Mod. 1931
ThingDef.description: Designed by Tullio Marengoni in 1931, the rifle was developed as a response to the Italian Army looking for a self-loading rifle

ThingDef.Name: SCOTTIMODX
ThingDef.label: Scotti Modello X
ThingDef.description: The Scotti Modello X was an experimental Italian semiauto design from the 30s. It was introduced in 1934 with a total of 250 made for trials.

ThingDef.Name: CEIRIGOTTI
ThingDef.label: Cei-Rigotti
ThingDef.description: The Cei-Rigotti was an Italian prototype self-loading rifle designed by Amerigo Cei-Rigotti. Notably featuring a select-fire function, the Cei-Rigotti was one of the first fully-automatic rifles in history.

ThingDef.Name: GUSTLOFFVSG
ThingDef.label: Volkssturmgewehr MP507
ThingDef.description: The Volkssturmgewehr MP507 was a self-loading rifle that was produced by Gustloffwerke during the late months of World War II.

ThingDef.Name: C98
ThingDef.label: Mauser C98 Selbstladegewehr
ThingDef.description: The C98 was Paul Mauser's initial self-loading military rifle design and first patented in Germany in 1898, it was test firing this design that cost Mauser the sight of his right eye during a breech explosion.

ThingDef.Name: HAGEN
ThingDef.label: Hagen Self-Loading rifle
ThingDef.description: The Hagen was a Norwegian prototype Semi-Automatic rifle that was tested by the French before WW1.

ThingDef.Name: HUNNESHAGENSLR
ThingDef.label: Hunneshagen M1924 Selbstladegewehr
ThingDef.description: The Hunneshagen M1924 was the early version of the later Hunneshagen semi-auto rifle. A very similar rifle made by Siemens was produced but no images remain.

ThingDef.Name: WFAK47
ThingDef.label: W+F AK-47
ThingDef.description: This is a self-loading rifle developed at Waffenfabrik Bern shortly after World War II. The designer of this rifle was Arnold Kipfer. The basic design of this rifle was inspired by the Soviet SVT and it was chambered for the Swiss 7.5mm rifle cartridge.

ThingDef.Name: MAS44
ThingDef.label: MAS-44
ThingDef.description: The MAS 44 comes from a line of French prototype rifles pre-dating WW2.

ThingDef.Name: WF1943
ThingDef.label: Selbstladekarabiner W+F 43
ThingDef.description: The W+F 43 was a prototype Semi-automatic rifle conversion of the K31 rifle. This rifle came with an integrated sniper scope.
